text: 22floz bottle, no freshness date, and paid the sale price $2. Its all downhill from the mediocre appearance; cloudy yellow in color and flowery aroma. Way too sharp and dry for my liking. Also, it tastes like bar soap. Blech, I couldnt make it past about a third of the bottle.
Bottle, if I´ll be a table beer I will be like this. Great job Brian. Thanks for this!

2012. Giallo paglierino, torbida, schiuma bianca non persistente. Aroma fresco e acidulo, con mela, agrumi e lievito. Al palato è piuttosto acidula, con una carbonazione spinta, secca nel finale. Note fruttate e funky. Interessante stile ma non totalmente il mio genere.

Bottle shared by Derek. Pours a slightly hazy light yellow with lasting white head. Aroma is faint Belgian yeast, some citrus fruit. Taste is surprisingly sour, finishes with some yeast. Really enjoyable and refreshing. Crushable.

Bottled. Old note. The aroma has citrus, light pepper, funk, orange peel. Hazy, golden coloured beer with a white, medium head. The taste is biscuity, light bitter, has funk, citrus, pepper. Nice, easy drinker.

Pajiza, amarillenta, bastante turbia y con buena espuma. Aroma cítrico y algo lácteo. En boca refrescante ante todo. Sabor sin duda asidrado, pero no desagradable del todo, porque se equilibra con tonos cítricos y yerbales (pino). Tono bastante seco, sobre todo al final. Conjunto difícil pero si le coges el truquillo no está mal. En cualquier caso, no vale lo que cuesta.

Bottle. Pours a clear orange color with a medium white head. A big funky brett nose, lemons. Huge funky, dirty sock, dry brett, some lemons, citrus is big but the overall beer is more dry than estery. Very smooth and tasty. A good intro to funky beers for people.
Bottle @ tht. Aroma is silty sourish lactic acid, some malty caramel and fruity hops. Flavour is light tangy wheat, fruity notes. Hint of lactic acid. Nice one.

Bottle shared thanks to jmgreenuk. Pours cloudy yellow with a ring white head. Aroma of citrus, fruity hops and Brett funk giving a nice barnyard aspect. Flavor is light sweet and bitter. Light bodied with light carbonation.

Bottle at the Jim goes to Malaysia tasting, Den Haag. Poured a hazy light straw colour with a thin broken white head. The aroma is yeast, earthy, light sweet malt, slightly creamy. The flavour is light sour, light bitter, with a lovely smooth, yeasty, toothpaste hop bitter palate. Light bodied with average carbonation. Really crisp and refreshing. Highly drinkable!
Bottle at Jim leaves for Malaysia tasting @ ABCBeers. Murky yellow pour. Aroma is quite bretty, spicy, vitamin C, yeasty and fruity. Flavor is slightly sour, spicy and very bretty. Messy, but decent.
Poured a milky light golden with an off white head. Aroma of musty fruit and Belgian yeast. Medium body, flavour is medium sweet, lightly astringent.

bottle courtesy of JMGreenUk @ Jim is moving to Malaysia tasting.
very thin white head. Very murky blond pour. Interesting beer. Some funkyness.

[Bottle, thanks for sharing, Guerde!] Pours cloudy golden with a rocky head which quickly fades. Aroma is ginger and carrot, leather, funkiness, and citrus (lime?). Taste is carrot, a surprising amount of bitterness, and funkiness again. Smooth, medium-thin, with a decent length finish. Overall, a really enjoyable beer that I would love to have available in reasonably priced 6 packs during the summer.
Bottle at a tasting. Cloudy gold color. Yeasty and dry, good carbonation and light spice with a dry finish. Nice session beer.

Draft at Dutchs from notes. Pours hazy yellow color with a large, frothy white head that lasts and provides excellent lacing. The aroma and flavor had Belgian yeast, barnyard character,earthy, apples and citrus fruit character, floral, pepper, some funk, pale malts, dry finish, pretty good character for a lighter table beer.

Cloudy lemmon with moderately thick white head. A lot of lemon on the nose, almost a bit too much (too much like cleaner), with a bit of hops and CO2. Bitter, peppery, hoppy, and full of CO2, which rather drowns out any flavor. Probably better drunk outside in the sun than in the damp indoors in winter.
Hazy yellow. Looks a lot like white grapefruit juice. Off white head. Big citrus aroma, followed by some yeast. Palette is very lively---quite a bit of carbonation initially---rather acidic finish.

A hazed blonde ale with a thick frothy lacing white head. In aroma, loads of what, biscuit malt with orange pulp, funk, Orval beauty, superb. In mouth, a well balanced Saison with light fruity biscuit malt, loads of Brett, orange peel, smooth, quaffable yet complex. Bottle was brought at NY central station, 3 years ago... Still beautiful.

In short: The ultimate bright sessionnable funky blonde ale.
How: Bottle 22oz, consumed with many months of age on it.
The look: Medium cloudy glowing blonde body topped by a medium white head leaving lots of lacings on the glass.
In long: Nose is in-your-face funky, a superb bright and clean brett character blending harmoniously with a vibrant tropical fruitiness. In mouth the beer has a fluffy-foamy texture supported by a very lively carbonation that is never aggressive, great mouthfeel. Taste has very crisp crackery cereals, fresh white bread, a lot of clean funk, fresh tropical fruits, mild acidity. The bright funk character and overall flavor profile was somewhat reminiscent of a Jolly Pumpkin Bam Bier but without the sourness of the Bam Bier and this made the Table Beer immensely sessionnable. I cannot think of a better beer that combines sessionnable and funk qualities. I loved that beer very very much and now Id really like to know how to tell the difference between a male bottle and a female bottle because I have a conscience problem here
Bottle from Archive Beer Boutique April 2013. Not earth shattering but not bad. Solid all round beer.

Pours a cloudy golden with copious amount of lacing white head that lingers on the glass. Aromas of lemon zest, coriander, wheat, and banana. Flavors of banana and coriander with hints of lemon coming through. Highly carbonated and very light in body. Easy to drink and makes you want to come back for more. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 ounce bottle into tulip glass, no bottle dating. Pours slightly hazy bright golden color with a 2-3 finger dense and fluffy white head with great retention that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Dense foamy lacing clings around the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of big lemon zest, orange peel, strawberry, pineapple, peach, pear, white pepper, wheat, cracker, hay, straw, grass, herbal, musty funk, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of fruity/spicy yeast, pale malt, and earthy hop notes; with great strength. Taste of lemon zest, orange peel, strawberry, pineapple, peach, pear, white pepper, hay, straw, grass, herbal, wheat, cracker, musty funk, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Good amount earthy bitterness/yeast spice on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon zest, orange peel, strawberry, pineapple, white pepper, hay, straw, grass, herbal, wheat, cracker, and herbal/yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice balance and complexity of fruity/spicy yeast, pale malt, and earthy hop flavors; with a crisp malt/spiciness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a very smooth, crisp, and fairly prickly mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is well hidden with zero warming present after the finish as expected of 4.7%. Overall this is a really excellent Brett session saison. All around great complexity and balance of fruity/spicy yeast, pale malt, and earthy hop flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A very enjoyable offering.

Magnifique tête qui a cette capacité dêtre mangée à la cuillère. Robe comme un champ de blé embrouillé. Nez franc de fleur de miel et de cuir avec de la paille citronnée et une dose de vitamine D. Bouche blanche et fruitée avec une poussière épicée et des herbes pleines de légèreté. Corps aérien, pétillant, plein de ces grandes soifs et des bonheurs chargés par la fraîcheur. Arrière-goût poivré, légèrement terreux, véritablement bretté. Excessivement facile à boire. Je dirais même plus, buvabilité folle. Bouteille en provenance du Parker Pie.
very fizzy big head straw yellow. Aroma of pine grapefruit hops bretta, lemons, mango. Tastes hay, dusty, herbal, rosemary, dank herbal firm bitter all the way through the finish. Dry finish yummy
Cloudy yellow colour. Yeasty, citrus, farmhouse aroma. Taste is yeasty, citrus, refreshing,

Drat pour. Pours a hazy gold with a big white head of foam. Good retention. The aroma is grassy, lemony and herbal. The taste is even keel with a drier, more bitter finish. Medium to high carbonation.

On tap at Dutchs. First pour from the keg. Totally hazy golden orange color. Pours with a big white pillowy head. Leaves good lace. Big bright citrus lemon hop aroma up front, light spice. Light belgian yeast. Good light earthy herbal mild funk to it. Lighter body. Smooth kind of soft bright and effervescent texture, moderate strength carbonation. Lightly dry finish. Moderate bitter taste, nice zestiness, light spice, light sweet. Pretty well-done, tasty complex table beer. I like the bigger hop character and subtle funk. Good stuff.
On tap at Black Sheep ale house..straw yellow pour, thin white head..aroma of banana,pear,hops..dry,crisp,refreshing,.bretts come through nicely.
Bomber. Pours hazy golden. Funk and fruity brett on the nose. Taste is much the same. Nice brett (trois?) dry/fruity finish. Nice session beer, good for kicking off a summer evening!
Pours a golden straw blonde with some haze and one finger of white head. Peppery and brett heavy aroma, very very bretty. Super dry and bretty flavor. Dry
Floral aroma, hoppy taste. Bitter hops, resin, clean drisp and smooth finish

Pours a fairly clear yellow, med white head with nice lacing. Aroma is piss, lemon, yeast, some basement must, light funk, citrus. Flavor is very crisp & clear (similar to above), really light malt, nice wheat flavor & crisp hop, light apple funk. Light body & average carbonation, easy and refreshing drinking.

Oh the nostalgia of a trip to the urinal! Funk dominates and imposes that distinctive shithouse smell. With notes of straw, lemon, funk, fermenting apples, yeast. Nice depth but funk is too overbearing.
Pours hazy straw color with foamy white head. Looks much like a wit. 
Very light palate. Apple juice, cereal, straw, yeast. Brett is refreshingly more repressed. Tickly bitterness. Reminds me of hairspray...perfumed.

The Sampler, Brooklyn tap: Pours a cloudy gold with a white head. Aroma is that characteristic Stillwater yeast, barnhouse funk, some light citrus. Taste is exactly what the aroma would have you expect. Plenty of dryness and spice to be had. Nice touch with the hops adding the tiniest bit of bite. Body is really nice for the comparatively low alcohol. Good stuff.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy yellow body with a small fizzy white head that faded to a thin covering. The nose is rather beautiful, lots of floral and yeasty notes over a clean light pale malt base. The flavor is light and delicate with lots of floral notes and a nice light hoppiness. Clean and soft pale malt base with a nice lingering finish. Excellent beer to pair with food, as I suppose is the intent. I really like this one.

Draft at Westbrook. Cloudy deep golden pour with a bubbly white head. Tons of yeast funk, citrus dry hopping, white pepper corns, and spices. Great spice following through on the tongue, with Brett funk, hay and generous amounts of piney, floral, and citrus hops buttering through the finish. Massive flavor for such low alcohol.

Bottle. Pours cloudy golden with a diminishing creamy thick off-white big head. Aroma is brett, citrus, pine, grass, tangerine, pepper, funk, hint of ripe pear and very mild honey. Taste is light sweet and light+ bitter. Body is near medium, texture is creamy, carbonation is moderate+. Finishes dry, crisp with tangerine and pine. Drink-ability is extremely high.

Bottle. Hazy yellow with a medium sized white head. High effervesence. Bretty barnyard, citrus, dusty, band aid. Medium body, oily texture, medium carbonation, little sweetness, light dry and bitter finish. Refreshing and highly drinkable.
Lost notes. Golden yellow with a nice little firm head. Yeasty aroma, dry finish, very quaffable but a bit one dimensional.

ivorywhite head that disappears fast with some lacing. yellow colour slight turbid. aroma of pepper, saisonlike, citrus, bit soapy, some brett funk, sour. taste like aroma with bitter, pine cone. dry mouthfeel, medium body and carbonation. not bad given the low abv.  bottle 65 cl

Bomber. Pours a champagne colored pour with a fizzy head. Actually smells like champagne as well, yeasty with fruity sweet notes. Taste is a mouthful of well carbonated yeast and light spice. Finish is dry and ends on the yeasty lighter side. Quaff Score 7 / 10

Pours a clear gold with a white head and aroma of fruits, spices, and hops. Taste is earthy, yeast notes with spices, cloves, lemon zest, with floral hops and a sweet, funky finish while well carbonated. Solid Belgian ale, lots of flavors

Hazy straw yellow with a tall fluffy white cap floating on top. Will what do we have here??? FUNK!! wasnt expecting that. Hints of lemon, funk, and mild other stuff permeate the aroma. Dry, tart, lingering bitterness. Lemon is the only thing I can name for sure. Funk, mild funk. This is doing nothing for me...... kind of boring.

Bottle:   Pale straw, albeit a bit dirty with sediment, small to moderate frothy white head, spotty lacing.   Its like a milky straw.   Soft floral and fragrant nose, a bit herbal and citrusy.   Moreso herbal on the tongue.   Remains somewhat sweet.   A bit wheaty.   Body and mouthfeel are moderate.   Assertive fragrant finish, wheaty, yeasty, eastery, a little spicy, herbal, with citrusy notes.   For a table beer, I can dig it.   At 4.7%, seems higher than most table beers.   Enjoyable.

650ml bottle, golden color, with a big rocky white head, nice yeasty, fruity, wild funky bretty, citrusy nose, with some light horse blanket, barnyard, lemon, grapefruit peel notes, with a lemon pie, earthy floral citrus, leafy, green tobacco leaf, hop accents in the aroma follows through on a medium-boided palate with a very crisp, good belgian fruity, wild funky bretty yeast, leathery, zesty citrus peel, mango, pineapple, pear character, with some flowery citrus, piney, leafy, grassy, tobacco hoppy flavours, with a lemon pie, light lemon marmalade, dusty undertone, leading towards a wild bretty, fruity yeastiness, lingering citrus, piney, leafy, dry hop bitterness finish.

Pours a cloudy yellow with a large rocky white head and good amounts of lace up the glass. Aroma is citrus, fruity, and a bit of a wild fermentation. Flavour is a wild(brett like), zesty citrus, grass, spicy, pepper, yeasty, mild bitterness and bready. Im definitely a fan of this one.
Une bière très fraîche aux arômes dananas au nez. Une bouche sèche et resineuse. Une belle couleurs jaune un peu troublé.

Bottle. Dizzy yellow with medium white head. Too much yeast or what it is making it look dizzy, but it hadn´t had time to settle. Aroma belgian yeast, brett, barnyard. Taste initially sweet, brett, barnyard, dry, malts. There´s a good reason why there´s so much fuss about Stillwater, they make great beers.
Really nice balanced quaffable beer. Some brett to make it dry and refreshing. Some hops in a resin aroma. Not too sweet, not too watery, not too bitter. Very well balanced summer beer.
Smell of citrus, hops, plastic, fruit. Pale amber colour, white foamy head. Aroma of plastic, pepper, citrus, hops. Sour, slightly bitter. Carbon is lively and plentiful. Fresh.

Bottle, which I poured into the entirely wrong glassware. Oh well. Very light in color, this comes out with a massive freakin head. The aroma is distinctly wild, rife with farmhouse funk. The beer drinks with the expected cloying bite of an open fermentation tank, musty, bready, yeasty, herbed, sweet. (#5258, 9/19/2013)
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is brett, sourness, citrus, yeast. Flavour is brett, sourness, citrus, yeast, spices. Nice beer.

Color dorado pálido con espuma blanca de burbuja pequeña. Aromas de fruta ácida, champán y cítricos. En boca es ligera con una textura maltosa muy agradable. El sabor está dominado por una acidez afrutada muy equilibrada con un amargoras bien resinoso y seco. Una delicia.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Hazy yellow pour with a small white head with good lacing and retention. Nose is very grassy and spice driven - lots of pepper and cloves. Really sessionable stuff. Lightly funky but more sour notes on the nose than in the taste. Peppery tropical fruit and heavy grass driven hops. Wild yeast is prominent. Very nice and quaffable
Pours light gold, white head. Nose of flowers, hay, spice. Flavour is brett, earth, leather, citrus. Finish is brett and earth. Very light mouthfeel. Quite nice.

Bottle from Ølhandleriet enjoyed at home
Golden misty, white head. Smells of malts, yeast esters, spices, hints of funk. Light sweet, peppers and spices, wild yeast and malts. Moderate bitter finish. A very nice session saison. Very drinkable, nice brett infusion
February 2013. Bottle. Malt, Belgian yeast, light fruit aromas. Cloudy yellow with a thin white head. Flavors of wheat, vegetable, malt, spice.

0.65l bottle from Øltorget shared at innflyttningsfest. This is a cloudy straw golden one, it has a nice medium sized just off-white top that never leaves the glass. Looks really good and it has an amazing lovely bretty aroma. I get fresh grassy hints, some banana zesty hints after a few swirles,. Lovely flavor also. So fresh, light and refreshing. It has a average carbonation level and a light oily mouthfeel. The brett is just dancing on my tongue here. Fresh grass and a little citrusy grapefruit. WANT MORE! 01.06.2013
Bottle share. Cloudy yellow. Oddly sour, muted citrus and fruit, yeasty aroma. Taste is a weird mix of thin and sour, dry punches. Inconsistent. Odd.

Pours hazy gold into a tulip. Bright white head with excellent retention recedes leaving spider lacing. Sweet tropical fruit and funk aromas. Crisp with band-aid, aspirin and funk front to back and into the lasting peppery cracker finish.

Bottle. Moderate to heavy hay and straw for the malt, moderate herbs and lemon for the hops, light leather and must for the yeast, with hints of pear, white wine, nutmeg and clove. Head is large, frothy, white with thick crausty lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is clear at first, murky on the last pour, medium amber. Flavor starts moderately to heavily bitter, then finishes lightly to moderately acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is light to medium, watery with a fizzy carbonation and a dry finish. Ful, nicely rounded aromas, the flavor though refreshing is a little flat. Overall a very nice Belgian Ale experience.

Bottle from Ølhandleriet, shared march 30th 2013. Hazy yellow body, huge white head. Funky brett, lemon and flowery aroma, taste of grapefruit, pepper, clove, brett and grass, dry and extremely refreshing. I wish this was more availible, and at a better price, then it would definately be my regular "table beer".

Bomber bought @ Olbutikken. Pours cloudy pale yellow with a creamy and frothy white head that slowly dissipates while leaving lots of sticky lacing and trace on the glass. Smell is fruity, yeasty and phenolic with crackers, hay, white pepper corns, lemon zest, overripe mango, frozen strawberries, watermelon rinds, white bread, dry soil, brett and barnyard. Taste is bitter, tiny sour, spicy, tiny fruity and slightly phenolic with crackers, black and white pepper corns, coriander seeds, lemon grass, dry soil, dry wood, lemon zest, brett, barnyard, lemon juice and hints of overripe tropical fruits and red berries. Mouthfeel is crisp, dry, slightly astringent and light bodied. Finish is bitter and spicy with crackers, hay, grapefruit rinds, lemon peal, black and white pepper corns, coriander, allspice and hints of metal and unripe mango. Very tasty and pretty much a perfect table beer.

Pour is a clear yellow with a large white head.  Aroma is fruity/funk from the brett.  Maybe some floral hops and maybe some pepper.  Flavor is at first like chewing on a sweet and sour candy.  Including the chalkiness. Then comes a bit of stone fruit.  Finishes bitter and a bit sour.  This thing is a brett overload.  A bit much for my taste.

Bottle, 22oz. An uclear one, golden in color, and topped by a small, dense, white head. Brett aroma, fruity and funky, with some peppery notes in the back, making me think theres some saison yeast in here too. Pale malts too. Dry on the palate, semi-soft on the carbonation. Quite bitter flavor, with funk and fruityness. Some faint spice notes in the far back. Not much maltyness. Bitter and fruity finish. Certainly a pleasant one, tasteful and easy drinkable, well worth a revisit or clone. 130614

Bottle. Pours cloudy golden with a white head. Aroma of funk, spices, some floral and fruity notes. Flavor is sweet and funky with some spices, pear and leather. Medium to thin body, lively carbonation.

Bottle 650ml @ Geokkjer
Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, brett, yeast and some fruits. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with a funky, yeast and fruity finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

Clear golden yellow pour with a thick rocky/frothy white head, thick lacing and lively carbonation .... aroma of funky barnyard (brett), little earthy and fruity yeast ...... taste is of brett, spicy peppery yeast, fruity hops, earthy/light piney hops, with some caramel bready malts .... mouthfeel is lively with a light slickness and a bitter hoppy dry finish .... solid and kind of thin, but very easy drinking

FOAM. This beer pours a pale yellow with lots of foam that sticks. Aroma of bubble gum (stated earlier) and a little floral. The flavor meets the aroma half way. However, this beer finishes dry and bitter. It's ok, but could be passed by.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 oz. bottle, pours a cloudy golden yellow with a large foamy white head. Aroma of spicy Belgian yeast, some fruity esters, a little funky notes, and some dry crisp crackery malt - wonderful nose. Flavour is quite spicy and dry, with notes of spicy Belgian yeast, dry biscuity malt and floral hops. Very flavourful, with a dry spicy finish. A little peppery finish too. Excellent stuff.

Bottle (22 oz). Thanks to  Graham! Clear golden with a medium white head and some lacing. Aroma of lemon, brettanomyces, fruits and malt... really fresh. Taste is sligthly sweet with lemon, brettanomyces, good but subtle malt backbone, fruits. Medium body. Dry, clean, crisp and fresh. Great balance. This is the ultimate refreshing/drinkable Belgian Ale. Wow!

650 ml bottle. Pours a sludgy yellow with massive head of big bubbles. Creamy aromas of yeast, beeswax, lemon, and funk. Tastes like a health drink with citrus, tropical fruit, apples, and vegetable notes. This aint beer, its a yeasty fruit punch.

Bottle to flute
Wax, lemon, Brett, horse blanket. Cloudy sludgy orange with a vibrant white bubbly head. Bubble gum, lemon,  pepper.

Bottle Lightly-hazed golden ale with a huge, frothy, white head. Small, tight, long-lasting cap. Theres an awful lot going on in the aroma for such a small beer. Complex notes of juicy, fruity hops are interwoven with fruity, clove-spiced pear and apricot-like esters and phenols. Light to medium-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and airy carbonation. The flavor is a well-balanced blend of pale malts, fruity esters, spicy phenols, and bitter, rindy hops. Crisp, peppery, dry finish.
Amber golden in color, hazy with a thin head.  Super Belgian yeasty flavor and finish Very tasty beer and good for a nice dinner beer for all.

On bottle from Ølhandleriet , Oslo. Golden /orange hazy color & good foam. Medium high aroma intensity, fruitiness, citrus , floral aromas, hops and nice brett. Medium body & complexity. Good bitterness. Very enjoyable
Poured from a 22 ounce bomber. This is filled with orange, green apple, brettanomyces, hay, slight mint, earthy. This is fantastic. I love the session wild ale. Big fruity and rustic character.

Bottle. Gold with a large white head that lasts well. Aroma of oranges, lemon, hay, flowers, mild funk, some shoe polish. Tart first with sweet oranges underneath; earthy and a little herbal, dry with zingy brett and a fair bit of bitterness at the end. All good stuff, but its very high contrast and comically unsubtle. Sediment in the second glass reduces the HULK IMPERIALIZE ALL THE NUANCES factor a bit.

22oz bottle picked up at Grassroots 
Appearance: Pours cloudy light golden with a big white head and lots of sticky lacing 
Aroma: Wet blanket, yeasty and fruit 
Taste: Funky, yeasty, fruity, oranges and a dry finish 
Very nice and tasty. Great flavors but light and delicate.

(22oz bottle, 2012 vintage)  Pours a golden body with a tall rocky white head.  Aroma of florals, grass, leather, and horse blanket.  Flavor of brett, floral, earth, grass, citrus, passion fruit, and stone fruit.   Damn good!  Well done, Brian!

Yellow-gold with massive, flotsam, white head / Dry, elegant, floral nose of citrus, coriander, truly big manure / Light body, a touch thin, with otherwise excellent balance, beautifully dry and bitter / Floral, perfumey flavors of orange peel, pear, passion fruit, coriander, manure / Weak of body, but at 4.7% its probably a direct result.  Great stuff.

Bottle from Total Wine, Naples. The pours light gold with a discreet white head that quickly fades. The nose is mild farmhouse yeast. Hints of banana and spring fruits. Marshmallow. The taste is super dry white grape, apple sauce. A bit of barnyard funk. Light zippy yeasty profile. Just a hint of brett. Quite dry on the finish. Light body, plenty of carbonation. Overall, a pretty good beer. Very drinkable.

Bottle: Poured a deep bright golden color ale with a huge pure white foamy head with excellent retention and great lacing. Aroma of dry Brett notes with light funky notes is very enjoyable and refreshing. Taste is also dominated by some notes of dry flora notes with light Brett and funky ester with light rustic malt backbone. Light citric notes are also easily perceptible. Body is about average with great carbonation. Very enjoyable beer that is not overly dominated by Brett but still retain a great balance between drinkability and complexity.

650ml bomber pours a golden color with a huge white head that retains well and leaves some decent lacing on the glass.  Aroma is funky with some fruit, earthy tones and yeast notes.  Taste is an earthy hop bitterness with some fruity and malty sweetness and a dry yeasty finish.  An interesting brew, but a little too funky for my tastes.
incredible light beer, easy to drink but very complex, dry finish, funk and tart, quite sour, citric and herbal notes. great beer
Draft. Amber beer with a cream head. Soap and spice aroma with light frutiiness. Spice and soap flavor with fruit. Medium bodied. Spice and soap linger with fruity esters.

650ml bottle - $9.49 at Minks Package Store in Marietta, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours a hazed, light straw-hued body with a lofty, foaming, white crown of suds. Meringue-like lacing.

Smell: A touch of hay-esque malts, a spritz of fresh lemon and lime, half of a pineapple ring, and some Brett notes. As some of the yeastier deposits from the bottle make their way into the glass from latter pours, it picks up a big, spicy, floral perfumy quality.

Taste: Light, mild-mannered pils malts, very low, sans-crust bready quality and just a hint of sweetness. Soft touch of lemon-lime citrus. A few drops of pineapple juice. Heck, maybe some green apple. Lightly bitter. Agreeable, leathery funk character. Coriander and fresh florals later on. A little bit of mineral and a rebound of oily, moist citrus on the staunchly dry finish. 

Mouthfeel: Light-bodied. Well carbonated for a nicely crisp mouthfeel.

Overall: Its a little hay-like malts, some funk, and a appreciated citrus, until youre brain is wrecked by the outstanding refreshment.

22 oz bottle.  Clear straw with a torrent of tiny bubbles and a meringue head that continues to build.  Nose is custard, sage, grass and lemon zest.  Crisp, tingly, vibrant and bright finishing smooth and creamy.  Taste is subtle grass, pine, honey and parsley.  Gets bitter with citrus peel and green banana.  Evokes a sunny afternoon; lovely.
Pours a cloudy pale yellow with a white lacing. Crisp and quenching. Fubky barnyard notes. Fluffy mouthfeel. devoid of sweetness.

Bottle. Hazy almost fluorescent yellow, foamy white head. Really nice looking beer. Nose is lemon, spices, orange coriander, very mild funk. Taste is spices, orange coriander, bittering hops. Smooth mouthfeel transitions well into dry finish. Really solid beer, just dont like the hints of orange coriander.
Bottle->stem.  Densely murky gold, thin white head.  Aroma is barnyard funk and vinegar.  Taste is bitter funk, hay, mold.  Not a fan.

22 oz. bottle from 2012.  A hazy straw pour with a thick and fluffy meringue-like off-white head that leaves chunks of lacing behind.  The funky aroma features lots of lemons, oranges, melon, bananas, zesty citrus rinds, grass, white pepper, candi sugar, light caramel, and the cheesy/athletes foot encrusted socks smell of Brett.  Goes down fairly thin with a high level of effervescence.  Kinda creamy here and there.  Sweet upfront taste-wise with some caramel, candi sugar, melon, and hints of bananas.  A bitter finish with juicy lemons, orange rinds, and wheatgrass.  A dash of pepper at the end.  Yeasty, dusty, and funky throughout.  Very drinkable.  Interesting.

Bomber. Pours lightly hazy gold with a tower of creamy, bubbly white head. Aroma is funky, spicy, pine, bretty esters. Taste is a blend of much of the same. Very fresh piney hop bite. Light, pleasant brett tang. Very crisp and light. Incredibly drinkable. Would be a great session drink.

Bomber. Pours a very slightly hazy medium golden shade. Vibrant streams of effervescent bubbles feed a billowing, tightly packed head of snow white froth. Tall, looping arches of pronounced, patchy lace mark the glass. The nose is fantastic, showing a dry, supremely well attenuated, bready malt base. Dusty brettanomyces funk lends notes of dried pineapple and high-quality aged, sharp white cheese. The wild yeasts also add softly sulfuric, eggy tendencies. Hops are abundant, lending ample grassy, piney aromatics. The flavor follows suit, sharp and dry, quite bitter with all the grass and straw notes. Distant tropical fruit adds a subtle fruity note. The sharp, dusty brett has beaten the malt into submission, yielding the driest possible remnants of bread crumb and cracker. The mouthfeel is perfect  bone dry, lightly prickly, and cleansing. The bottle disappears way too quickly. This is an absolutely phenomenal beer, one that Ill likely go through is mass quantities while I can get it. Watch out Bam Biere...theres a new kid on your block.

Bottle. Pours a clear pale gold with a fluffy white head that lasts throughout the beer. Aroma has a nice flora note with some grassiness and a nice light earthy funk underlying. Flavor begins with a good amount of grass and light grain and has a hint of flora and a growing funk note. Finish is quite dry.

Draft. Very cloudy golden color with a medium white head. A yeasty aroma with hints of banana. Medium body with heavy barnyard flavors and a strong bitter hop finish. Im on the fence. Complex flavors and strong bitter finish are a bit much.

22oz bottle.  Large white head atop cloudy apple cider body.  Aroma is medium sweet, spicy/white pepper, some banana, earthy.  Taste is medium sweet, white pepper, some dusky, earthy, light cantaloupe, banana.  Light-medium body, some acidity, fairly dry finish.

1/3/13. 22oz bottle from Grassroots Natural Market. Hazy golden pour with a huge, fluffy off-white head that sticks and coats the glass with clumpy lacing all around. Fruity Brett aroma with yeast esters, light funk, citrus, and a fair dose of hoppy bitterness. Nice Brett flavor as well with more citrus and esters and again a solid bitterness from the hops. This is really good and extremely drinkable. If it were cheaper, Id buy a ton to keep in the fridge and drink.

Bottle. Appearance: cloudy golden yellow with huge fluffy white head that lingers some once it dissipates. Aroma: huge barnyard, big lemon, some pepper, and hay. Taste: very similar to aroma with lemon upfront and earth and hay coming in thru the end with that lingering funky Brett yeast. Mouthfeel: light but creamy (if that makes sense) with mid to high carbonation. Overall:  fits the name. Very sessionable with big hearty rustic meal. Very bright, refreshing and dirty, earthy at the same time.

Bottle. Pours cloudy lemon yellow with white head. Nose/taste of lemon, wild yeast, citrus, lemony bread and light earthy notes. Finishes quite dry with slight wild yeast/brett. Some light funk. Lighter bodied. Great session beer.

Belmont bottle, probably 6 months old or so. This is a true-to-style Belgian ale; hard to believe this was made in the States. Pours with a massive, merengue head that lasts forever. Nice little hop kick in there. Classic.

Pale, clear golden color with a big white head. Aroma is spicy, almost like black pepper or spicy leafy greens. Flavor is also very peppery but light and playful as well. Finish is very clean with just a touch of yeast. Strong flavors for such a light beer. Pretty nice.

The was a draft pour at THE LOCAL Beer Bar in Eureka, CA.  Came in the glass a cloudy gold with a nice creamy white head.  Light lacing. Nose is citrus, some citrus, tropical fruit, and brett. Medium body. Smooth in the mouth. The flavor is of light citrus and stone fruit .The finish is nicely bitter and balances the brett well. Very nice and would make a super session beer.

Good looking pour: tons of head, sticky lace. Lemony aroma accents the fizzy yeast. Highly carbonated, works well. Light on the palate, quite drinkable -- tasty too. And that's what a table beer is all about, no?
Pours yellow with tiny head.  Grain smell.  Light, sweet flavors like citrus fruit.  Plenty of hops.  Bitter finish.

A - Pours a clear golden-orange with a big finger of frothy white head. The head fades down at a slow pace leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of Belgian yeast, farmhouse smells, spices, some funk, lemon zest, and sweet grainy malts.

T - Starts off with a mix of sweet grainy malts, some tart lemon zest, some spices, and some citrus hops. Through the middle, some more Belgian yeast character comes through with some farmhouse flavors, some funk, and some peppercorn. The finish is a mix of sweet grainy and bready malts with Belgian yeast, some farmhouse flavor, some peppercorn and other spices, and some tart lemon zest.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a dry, tart, and funky finish.

D - Very drinkable. Nice BPA with a good Belgian yeast character.

Bomber from TW. Hazy straw-gold pour with a huge rocky head leaving heavy lace. Nose is quite strong in plastic band-aid, with some spices and yeast. Light body with vigorous, sharp carbonation. Lots of estery Brett funk, but still quite dry. Some lemon, yeast, earth and pine hops too, but the Brett character predominates. Depending on how this one is handled, I think the live nature of the bottle may get itself in trouble.

Funky, funky, funky. Smells and tastes as if it was brewed with herbs and soil. Definitely earthy! Interesting, thoughtful and complex, with layers of herbs and funky earth notes. A controversial beer.. You'll either love it or hate it.. I loved it for its unique qualities. 

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

22oz bottle pours a lightly hazy, bright gold with some fluffy, lasting white head.  Nose is perfume, a little bit of pear cider, grass, hay, some light lemon, a little light cheese, some light funk.  Very inviting.  Flavor is nice, sweet, light honey, light grassy, lightly cheesy, a little yogurt, some lemon, a little lemongrass, something a little medicinal, lavender, some high end soap.  Dry and crisp finish.  Exceptionally well balanced.  A bit over priced at $12 for a bomber.  If this was $8.99 it would be a regular selection for me.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2014 Bottle with Linh, Vi & Thi, Ken and Nicca at Bier Merchants in Brooklyn after Zwanze day. Pours a clear amber golden body with nice white head. Aroma is light lemon Brett, spicey esters, light wheat, and freshly cut grass. Mouthfeel is medium to thin with nice carbonation and notes of grass, yeast, earthy hops and light lemon. Very nice, refreshing session beer.

Botle.  Well this is quite this nice little bia.   Notes of lemon, grass, spruce,  some sweat and barnyard.  Awesome balance between the lemon zest and funk.  Clean.  Well made.   One of my favorites from stillwater.  Complex.   Neat to try.
Draft.  Poured a slightly hazy pale gold with a largish white head.  Aroma and flavor were moderately bitter, quite funky.  Some nice floral brettiness.  Bit of citrus.  Fine carbonation.

On draft at Pizzeria Paradiso in Dupont Circle. Pours a hazy yellow straw color with a smallish white bubbly head. Nose and flavor bring lovely combinations of soft lemon flesh, grassy hops, fresh bread dough, a pleasant floral component, and touches of cheesy funk. Quaffable and beautifully dry on the palate. Really delightful brew.
Pours cloudy blond, very pale with awesome lacing. Good head. Smells like cider. On saison side on belgian ale. Nice crisp dose of sour. Very good. On tap at blue monk.
22 ounce bottle from Shenanigans.  Big carbonated pour. Yeasty, funk aroma. Yeasty funk taste. Some peach. Dusty - a description Ive seen attached - holds. Nice funky brett beer.

Bottle. Slightly hazed gold pour with a tall, frothy white head. Slightly funky yeast notes in the aroma along with earthy notes, dried flowers, strong herbal notes, light medicine, straw, cut grass and dried fruit. Taste is huge herbal notes, light medicinal notes, funky yeast, earthy hops, dried flowers, dried tropical fruit, toasted malt, straw, cut grass, spice and lemony notes. Body is light and extremely effervescent. Finishes with more herbal notes, strong earthiness, floral notes, funky, dusty yeast, horse blanket, grass, straw and dried fruit.

Pours hazy gold with a frothy white head. Nice tart fruit, Brett aroma. Slightly tart in flavor, Brett, white pepper, lemon zest. Light feel, soft carbonation. Very nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Refrigerated brown bomber poured into a trappist glass.  Pours clear pale golden with medium fluffy bright white head.  Some small bubble lacing, light body, medium carbonation, and nice brett/yeast aroma.  Taste is effervesent pale malt, spicy yeast, brett, slightly toward the end bitter hops, and slightly dry finish.  I like this better than bitter XX, but not as well as westy blonde.

Bottle. Pours a lightly hazed straw yellow color with a nice fluffy white head. Nice Brett aroma of florals along with some citrus. The taste is nice and light with the Brett florals dominating. Some bitterness in the back end. Overall, a very enjoyable beer. Would drink more if it was available.

650 mL bottle from Amity Wines, New Haven. Pours a hazy orange color with a large foamy white head. Decent head retention. Aroma of stone fruits, brett, yeast, spice. The taste is dry, earthy and funky. Plenty of brett and a spicy finish. Medium bodied and quite drinkable. Nice beer.

Absolutely not a fan of this.  10 karat pour with a nice ivory head.  Musty, funky, cheese and pepper-filled brew.  Funky, Brett, doughy.  Spice and horse blanket.  I know!  Sounds delicious!  Right up my alley...nope.  Muddled, disjointed, and actually a bit offensive.  Messy.

Bottle from Johns Grocery. Pours pale golden color with fluffy white head. Strong brett aroma with some fruitiness and doughiness. Light  funkiness and tartness with brett flavors. Light body with lively carbonation and a dry finish.

Pours hazy pale yellow, huge frothy white head. Lots of lacing. Nose is phenolic yeast, lemon, funk, oak, subtle grass. Sour Brett yeast, oak and light lemon once on the palate. Dry and clean though slightly thin bodied. Excellent drink ability for the ABV. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Clear golden straw pour with large billowing bright white head.  Smells and tastes of pure brett.  With hint of lemon zest and fresh floral notes like chamomile. Hints of slight toe cheese.  Palate produces the typical bretty dryness. I would have pegged this as a bretty saison.  lingering grassy hop bite on the tail.  Pretty damn good for the style, but I wouldnt want it again.

Bottle from whole foods.  Pale golden color, nice white head. Smoothe, balanced fruity-funky flavor ends with a hop bite that hangs in there. Granted, this is not a style I'm passionate about, but overall reaction was "meh." Definitely not bad, but not memorable either. 

The elaborate description on the bottle & price raise expectations higher than warranted.   Too expensive to actually be a "table beer" for me.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I picked up this bottle from Bruisin Ales while visiting Asheville, NC.  The pour is a golden color with a thick off-white head.  Great head retention leaves scattered lacing on the glass.  This has a funky bretty aroma; lots of vibrant floral notes here.  Citrus, grass, white grape, and a little wood round out a really nice scent.  The flavors are a bit tart, very dry, and clean.  I just love how this drinks.  Theres a little oak in there with a white wine character, funky brett, dust, lemon, and grass.  It just glides along so well leading to a bone-dry finish that has me anxiously awaiting the next sip.  I had to (somewhat unsuccessfully) guard against drinking this one too quickly.  Its just so thirst quenching, clean, and tasty.  Stillwater continues to impress.  I cant think of a single thing wrong with this beer.  This is even better than the Premium I had recently and that one was world class.

RBAG - From the RBAG commemorative glass - Pours hazy gold, thin white head, right proper and solid lacing (Note: This is verbatim from handwritten notes from the middle of a quite extended tasting session, I dont normally sound like such an asshat). Nose is perfume, violets, Ponds cold cream, grapefruit, cardamom, plenty of spice here. Flavours of cream, violets, spice, pepper, phenomenally balanced and flavourful for such a low alcohol content.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2012 Bottle from AZ Wine.  Pours a light straw color with steady varbonation and mounds of foam and lacing.  Smells and tastes of pils malt, pears, and lemon zest.  Mild hops on the finish.  Really easy drinking. Im a fan.

Bottle. Light yellow pour with a lot of tan head. Spice forward aroma, sage, yeast and hop tones. Bitter hop forward with light citrus, spices and herbal tones, flavor is full although subtle. Very nice drinkable beer, great job!

Draught at the Beer Table, Brooklyn, NY.
Hazy orange golden colour with small white head.
Brett yeast and malt in delicious aroma.
Excellent hoppy bitterness accompanied with Brett yeast. 
Simple but extremely tasty. Lovely!

Bottle, shared at RBAG 2012 Summer Session. Cloudy light yellow with a large white head that leaves nice lace. Aroma is lightly malty with tart fruit accents. Palate is super-light! But bursting with refreshing flavours of rhubarb, lemon, celery, light sour apple. Lightly yeasty, smackingly tart. Crazy drinkable, refreshing. This was a pleasant surprise.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: RBAG Summer Session 2012. Clear yellow color with a medium white head. Funky aroma with citrus and malty notes. Flavor starts bitter and crisp, then moves to tropical and stone fruits before a citrusy finish. Very nice.

Bottle via SL... Very light golden orange color... Nice two finger head.  I picked this up thinking it was a pale ale... but to my surprise and liking, this beer has a nice tart taste. Lots of grassy, lemon, earthy, fruity flavor, slight hop crisp light character. Tons of flavor for such a low alcohol brew. Really impressed. Very light body, medium/high carbontion level. But light and fluffy. Overall: Great beer.

22 oz bottle purchased at Royal in Kansas City, Missouri.  The pour is clear golden, with effervescent carbonation bubbkes and a three inch fluffy egg white head. The head is slow to fall, eventually leaves behind a sheet of lace. The aroma is dry cracker malt, nice zesty lime citrus and a nice touch of leathery earthy Brett yeast. There is a spruce element too that adds nicely to the overall fresh and clean character of the nose. The taste is graint, earthy, hay, then moves to the citrus notes, pine needles, and finishes bone dry with the leathery Brett. As it warms, the pine and Brett really take over, giving a nice bite and dryness. The palate is light bodied, soft natural carbonation, and the great dry finish. Super drinkable, each sip begs for the next. I really enjoyed this beer.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2013 pour is a hazy golden yellow with a dense white head and a few larger bubbles. The nose is nice, light brett, heavy fruit presence, apricots and tropical stuff, light hop presence, oily and sweet. The taste is a bit less expressive but still very nice and balanced.   Great gentle Brett presence, fruity and nice, tropical flavors, apricot, light hop, oily and a touch sweet. Light body, refreshing and crisp carbonation.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2014 Bottle from Whole Foods Roosevelt.

This is very close to a perfect biere de table.  Big white head atop a hazy color of unfiltered pineapple juice. Mellow, sour-funk aroma married to a lightness of yeasty esters. The flavor is where it comes into its full glory. Mineral and lightly sulfered (less so than Avril), just barely tart, grapefruit pith through the middle, bitter bretty finish. Great big flavor and full mouthfeel, certainly not hindered in the least by its low ABV. Brilliant. A ten for flavor is not out of reach here.
With regard to desert islands: If I could drink only one beer for the rest of my life, this one would top out Orval in a sufficiently hot climate.

Revisit 7/25/14 after a soccer game. This one of the ones that merits the high rating I originally gave it. Lovely brett-driven ale.

Bottle at Monks Cafe. Hazy blonde amber with a big frothy white head. Slightly sour and sweet but mostly very dry. Oaky barrel flavors. Green grapes. Apple seeds. Grassy. Lemon zest. Vinus apricots. Orange blossom honey. Powdery dry on the tongue. Fizzy carbonation. Brett is there but the sugar is low such that there is not too much funk. Nice strong saison.

2012 bottle date; Sampled July 2012
A steady pour into my small St. Sebastiaan tulip produces a three-finger thick, frothy, just tan tinged, off-white colored head. The beer is a yellow gold color that shows a brilliantly clear, pale, straw-gold hue when held up to the light.  The aroma smells of herbal and lemon like hops, it has a substantial phenolic character that leans towards plastic, perhaps a hint of rubber and a bit of medicinal chemicals (all in a good way, and all seemingly Brettanomyces derived), and perhaps just a hint of dried grassy and cracker like malt, but this last is quite subtle.

The beer has a nice carbonation, a quite light body, but has a surprising amount of body to it considering the Brettanomyces and the alcohol level. There is a nice, chewy, wholesome, pale malt graininess in the middle, and the finish has a biting hop bitterness to it that melds with a touch of yeast derived spiciness as well as a touch of herbal hops and phenolic plastic like character. There is a soft lemon character to this beer that seems to be hop derived, as well as some pine-like and green herb character. The malt flavors that this beer has are quite nice, it is all from the pale malt, but it complements the hops and light funkiness quite well; without this cracker-like, and dried straw backbone, this beer wouldnt be anything near what it is. This has a spiciness that lingers on the tongue after each sip; peppery, perhaps a touch ginger like, and with a very soft fruitiness that has suggestions of ripe, floral pears. The fruity notes from the yeast and hop character comes out a bit more as this beer warms up.

A fantastic beer, that is just about always going to be something I crave. I am a sucker for these lower alcohol, slightly funky, hoppy, full flavored but exceedingly quaffable type beers. Again, if these werent such a staple of my brewing, I would be buying these all the time.

Definitely funky.  This is a truly tasty beer, but not really a table beer at its price.  Regardless, the beer works very well, yeasty aftertastes.  Hops are noticeable but not overpowering.  Taste is strong for the abv.

2012 bomber in celebration of my new job at UPenn!  Pours lively and bright, slightly hazy golden yellow, topped with a 4-finger eggshell head with long retention.  This recedes to leave spotty, blebby lacing, and a dollop of meringue-like lacing floating on top.  Huge pineapple aroma with dusty citrus, orange, and grass.  Moderate Brettanomyces, with some citrus tartness.  The flavor is dusty, funky orange, pineapple, and mango, with lightly bitter grass.  Peppery, slightly spicy citrus and pine finish.  The final pour dredges up some sediment, giving a more bitter and spicy final glass.  Medium carbonation and body, insanely drinkable, creamy, and dry.  Really really nice.  [1090]

Bottle poured a hazy lemon custard with a huge white frothy head and notable lacing.  Aroma is big on citrus and Brett with hints of honey, black pepper, and floral notes.  Taste is tart upfront before citrus is introduced and then palatable floral bitterness.  Really drinkable and a crisp finish that begs for another sip.  Wonderful session ale that will get even better with age.

Hazy dark golden color with a large, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of brett, citrus fruits, honey, vanilla, some leather, and funk.  Taste of honey, citrus, vanilla, brett, light sulfur, some bitter hops, and a dry, funky finish.  Could see the sulfur and bitter hops diminishing with time, and really becoming nice in about 3-4 months.

Bottle ($11.49). Gusher. Pours with a murky yet very pale golden hued body with a large, rocky white head that has great staying power. Good lace as well. Aromas are estery, pineapple, rusting, lots of earthy and peppery phenolics. Brett, earthy, herbal hop notes. Buckwheat, black pepper, dried fruits. Low nutty notes. Flavors are dry, lightly tart. Bitterness is a bit sharp at first, and a touch astringent. Herbal. Some fruit esters up front (under ripe pineapple). Medium phenolic. Juicy. Unripe stone fruit. Low grainy notes. Bitterness lingers. Dry and slightly bitter balance overall. Very lively bubbles, bone dry, lighter bodied. Very nice, but way to expensive to make a habit of.

Pour at Scotts saison tasting, pour out of 22 oz bottle is hazy yellow with white head, aroma has notes of some slight vegetable, lemon, earth, some slightly odd musty funk, some vanilla, honey, biscuit and spicy yeast come through.  Taste is sweet fruit, vegetable, biscuit, some earth, yeast, grassy notes with a touch of pepper, funky earth comes through finishing fairly dry.

22oz bomber-purchased at Wine and Cheese in St Louis, MO-pours lightly hazy lite orange hue with a huge soapy foamy white head that lasted the entire time-Brett seems to do this to beers.  nose is all brett bomb, no complaints here-some lite hops in there but doesnt seem as punchy as the label would suggest.  I wonder how old this beer is?  however, the nose is still fantastic-lots of brett funk, lite dusty esters and lite piney hops.  flavors have mostly brett funk and lite bitterness from the said hops.  a very good beer with lots of flavor for this low of abv-better than jester king prince yet not as good as Drinkin the sunbelt!

Herb-bitterer Beginn mit deutlichen Kräuternoten, wenig süß. Im Mittelteil bitterer werdend, womit auch eine gewisse Trockenheit einhergeht, die in diesem Fall aber kaum stört. Schwieriger aber erfrischender Abgang. 9/10/8/11//11

Tap at Of Love & Regret, cloudy goldenrod pour with a tight, white head (like all of Brians beers!).  Lacing coats the glass. Pinot Gris aroma with a slightly funky yeast. Taste is crisp and clean with Brett "peat" flavors standing tall. Winey, citrussy, and yeasty. Very tasty and great with food.
Sample at festival in Worcester, MA. Great flavor and drinkAbility, citrus hops, slightly herbal, flavorful and I could drink this all day
Bottle.  Pours a hazy golden color with big white head.  Spicy, citrus, yeasty, and straw aromas. Earthy, citrus hop, and some funky flavors.  Interesting, drinkable beer.

Sampled at an esbls tadting.  Hazy straw color with a soapy white head.  The nose is yeast and farmhouse funk.  First sip offers biting hops.  Itbis quite bitter.  Some grass and yeast.  Bitterness fooled me.

Draft. Hazy gold pour, small white head, good retention/lace. Aroma of stone, citrus/floral/grassy hops, tart, spicy yeast, earth. Taste is moderately bitter, grassy/floral hops, lightly tart, stone, cracker, lemon. Palate is bone dry, lively carbonation, bitter finish. Another great session beer.

Tap. Fluffy two fingers of creamy off-white head. Murky bright golden lemon yellow. Slight funk, lots of nice citrus hop, mango, peach and earth in the aroma. Flavor follows closely to the taste, much more mango rind, hay, pineapple, and a minerally and earthy dry finish. Very soft body wit lively carbonation. Nice

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2014 murky gold, puffy white head. Nose is more tangerine than premium, less Brett more grain and fruit, pine liquor and cedar throughout, bit of saltwater. Flavor is heavy citrus and grassy hops, dusty hay mid with bright mango and dusty hop finish. So balanced, light with carbonation.

22 ounce bottle.  Served in a tulip, the beer pours a slightly hazy gold color with an inch and a half off-white frothy head.  Head retention is excellent, and theres a good amount of lacing.  Aroma is very nice, the brew smells like hay, peppery spice, pears, brett, lemon peel and some earthy hops.  It tastes like sage, pepper, lemon peel, hay, brett and a little bit of bubblegum.  Mouthfeel/body is light/medium, its smooth but has a little bit too much carbonation for me.  I think its a good overall brew.  Low in alcohol, but full of flavor!  Its definitely worth trying.

Tap at Of Love & Regret - quasi- Orval clone here - fuck yea - hazy gold, with a huge, frothy, Orval-esque head - soooo dry and flinty, with some lovely, moderately funky phenolics that play off of the dry qualities and peppery bitterness/flavor of the hops extremely well - light in abv, but with full, soft carbonation and a fullness to the body that you do not normally find in a brew like this - awesome beer.

Bomber poured a hazy gold with a lingering ring of white foam. Aromas of earthiness, straw, citrus and chalk. Palate was lighht bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of straw, chalk and light citrus with a crisp dry finish.
Draft. A light golden beer with a lazing white head. The aroma has notes of hops, flowers, and drying hay. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, flowers, and hay. The body is light.

I expected to like this one, but not as much as I did.  This was a home run.  Pours hazy golden / orange with a large white soapy head.  The aroma has funky / buggy yeast, under-ripe tart fruit, mild toast and some spiciness - really pleasant smelling.  Light crisp grainy/husky body with a decent amount of frothy and sharp carbonation.  The flavor starts very dry and has some sulfur to it, like in some pilsners  There is also pepper, barnyard like yeast from the brett, hints of fruit and a touch of cracker.  The finish has more sulfur, a hop bite and some nectar fruits.  This is a fantastic beer.  It reminds me of a light version of Orval with some pilsner qualities.  Kinda the best of all worlds for me.

Bottle. Poured clear pale color with an average to large frothy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy fruit, citrus and yeast aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy spice sweet flavor with a medium spice sweet finish of moderate duration. I would recommend this to a friend.

Draught @ [ Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2012 ] @ Spartas Lokaler, Faelledparken in Osterbro, Copenhagen, Denmark.Clear medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted. pale malt, moderate to heavy yeasty, leather, saison, fruity, peper notes. Flavour is moderate to light heavy sweet and light moderate bitter with a average to long duration, dry. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120511]

Bottle @ Scotts Summer Saison tasting. Thanks so much Scott! Milky/cloudy yellow appearance with a small white head. Spicy onion/veggie, lemon spritzy, a bit bready aroma. Tangy, veggie, bitter herbal hoppy, fairly dry, light fruity flavor.

Tap @ Copenhagen Beer Celebration, 2012. Slightly hazy golden with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, yeast, spices, hops and a little citrus. Flavour is malt, fruit, dry, yeast, hops, spices and a little bitter.

Tap @ Copenhagen Beer Celebration, 2012. Pours slightly hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of malt, grain, fruity, peach. Taste is sweet with malt, grain, sweet fruit, peach. Thin to medium body, lively carbonation. 110512
CBC. Hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity, light bretty and yeasty. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 110512

Draft @ CBC 2012. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty slightly yeasty bretty aroma. Fruity malty yeasty hoppy bretty flavor. Has a fruity malty bretty finish with hints of citrus.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Hazy golden-straw body.  Medium sized white head, spotty lacing.  Huge brett component up front.  Hay, earth, lemon, soft spicing, and barnyard funk dominate both the aroma and flavor.  Nice balance of complexity and ease of drinking.  Really nails the concept of "table beer" in every aspect but the price.

From tap. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is brett and smooth fruity, crisp hoppy. Bitter, herbal and bretty. Fruity. Smooth hoppy and light fruity. Bitter and citrusy finish.

Draught at CBC 2012.

Hazy golden coloured with a medium sized white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of hops and spices with notes of barnyard and brett.
Fruity flavour of spices, barnyard, hops and grass.
Hoppy finish.

Had a sample of this and figured I should grab a full bottle. Yellow pour with a nice sized white head. Yeasty juicy fruit aroma, similar flavor. I really liked the brett in this, very fruit forward and balanced well with the hops. Quite dry finish, plenty of carbonation. I was pretty sad when the bottle was empty.
Nice little sessionable summer beer. Golden with a white head. Brett dominates the nose. High carbonation, and a bit of a gusher. Minty flavors dominate through the dry finish.

Draught at CBC. Light hazy golden with a small white head. Aroma is enticing: yeasty, fruity, grainy, light tart, fresh, vineous even. Taste is crisp, superdry, quite bitter, fruity with a light earthy finish. Very elegant with a light, graceful body.
Bottled.  Poured a pretty slightly hazy yellow.  Citrusy brett aroma and such.  Sour and funky. Pretty decent.

Light yellow, big foamy, fluffy head. Very spicy aroma - I get a lot of stuff going on here - orange, coriander, some other spices, some peppery notes. Flavor also pretty complex - rose hips, citrus, spices. Very tasty. I would drink this a lot if I could get it here...

Draft courtesy of Brian, thanks! Hazy golden color, small white head, delicate lacing. Aroma of bretty, dusty lemons, taste has light citrus and decent barnyard funk. Really nice, i could drink this all day!

Draught @ CBC 12
Aroma is light with earthy notes, some citrus and wheat. Flavour is sourish with earthy notes, citron and wheat. Similar to Jester King one, this one has more body (and ABV).

Thanks to yourefragile for sharing this one.  Served in a SAVOR wine glass.  Pours a clear pale straw color with a very nice white head.  Good retention and plenty of sticky lacing on the way down.  The nose is beautiful with notes of hay and light earthy hops with a touch of very light citrus in the background. Flavor is hay and straw with a light, yet still brisk, bitterness.  Light body and quite dry with excellent carbonation.  Über solid.  Put this one in cans too, please!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle that I had on the train on the way back from Where the Wild Beers Are.  Musk on the nose, bretty, grain, crisp and grainy.  Very green, bright and young.  Musk and lemon, crisp citrus and grain.  Softly musky, toast, light funkiness.  Earthy.  Long muskiness, funky and loaded with dry brett.  Very sessionable, but at $14 a bottle its an expensive session.  Still damned delicious though.

650 mL bottle. Pours pale yellow, with a large, foamy, white head. The aroma is lemons, salt, rocks, and pine. The flavor is metallic, faintly citrusy, and very sour. The aftertaste is long and intensely sour, to the point that it is difficult to continue drinking. The palate is medium, hard and clingy. Overall, this is an undrinkable mess of a beer. Very disappointed.

651mL from Foodery Northern Liberties, Philly PA. Beautiful hazy golden pour, larger suddy white head with good rockiness and soapy to webby lace. Nose is gorgeous Brett B cedar, huge herbal character, fresh zesty grass, morning barnyard, mild funky manure and horse blanket/hay. Perfect nose for style. Taste is light, aerated, herbal, mildly bitter, sharpy carbonated with huge quenching and refreshment. Carbonation is a bit too sharp. Definitely my favorite Stillwater beer so far apart from BA Cellar Door. Probably helped that this was brewed at Westbrook instead of at DOG Brewing. Sort of a much funkier version of Dupont Avril. Not sure why this doesnt count as saison. (????)

Sample at the Twelve Percent Imports tasting at Ale Wine & Spirits on 4/20/12. Clear yellow color with a medium white head. Funky aroma with citrus and malty notes. Flavor starts bitter and crisp, then moves to tropical and stone fruits before a citrusy finish. Very nice.
Very floral nose with light honey and golden fruit esters. Dry with crisp malt, some citrus fruits and hay, funky yeast. Terrific stuff.

Bottle from Stateline. Slightly hazy pale yellow pour. Very aromatic with fruity notes, peach maybe pineapple. Very floral.  Flavor is nice and light and dry. A bit Bready with tones if tree fruit and hints of bubble gun.  Very bitter dry finish. Really nice beer.

Growler picked up minutes before boarding the train at Grand Central to New Haven, halfway through the trip the growler was empty & it was realized that we should have bought 2, 1 growler was like .1 growler to us.... probably should have gotten 10 growlers in retrospect. 

Pours a golden color with a big white head and some lace. 

The aroma is peppery with a very light banana character. The bouquet is fruit forward but not particularly sweet and has some nice dusty notes. 

The flavor is dry, lightly spicy and very peppery. The hop character is well defined, leafy, and fruit forward without being overly "fruity" if that makes good sense? The beer is nicely bitter, very flavorful with a long finish. Terribly easy to drink.
Hazy yellowish pour, white head. Holy road apple aroma!  Straight up old leather and horse manure. Flavor is lightly tart, funk, bitter, lemons and stank barn aromas.

Bottle from Sams.  Fuck yeah.  Hazy orange golden with a big, fluffy white head in my fantome tulip.   Lots of lace. This glass definitely encourages large heads.   Clean, bretty nose, lots of pineapple, earth, funk. Flavor is nice, some peach and pineapple, clean minerals, light citrus and tropical fruits.   Just like I wanted this to be.  Very similar to Premium, but maybe a touch cleaner.  Keep making these Brian, theyrrrrrrrrrreeeee great!

22. Pours a cloudy medium-golden pale orange. Tons of creamy white mousse and tons of white lace. Nose of floral notes, toffee, white pepper, and blood oranges. Fantastic combination of esters and hop oils playing off each other. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Caramel and toffee under big waves of white pepper and piney resin, super-dry finish stops just short of shampoo. Very, very crisp, delicious, and refreshing. For once the marketing description tells you exactly what you need to know about a beer--this is clearly a beer designed to succeed where many others had failed and do something well that few others were equaling. There are a lot of great things to say about this beer, but the fact that it does all this on the high wire of 4.7% is one of the most interesting. This is the kind of beer that makes me seriously consider a kegerator.

Sample at Ale Wine & Spirits in Powell on 04/20/2012. Hazy yellow-gold pour with a medium white head that burns away steadily. Spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma of yeast, spicy hops and fruit. Light body with a mild funk character and notes of mild hops, peppery yeast and fruit. The finish is dry and tart with a funky brett aftertaste. Pretty good light Belgian Ale overall.

Bottle from Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours cloudy blonde with a modest off-white head and a citrus aroma. There is a hearty caramel malt flavor with a yeasty banana taste and a nicely bitter carbonated finish.

Bottle. Pours hazy yellow/gold with thick, frothy white head; decent retention and some lacing. Aroma is lemon and other citrus, straw and cereal malt, floral hops, light yeast, and light spice. Flavor is balanced malt and hops (medium bitterness) with supporting citrus esters; dry, semi-sweet finish. Light body, medium carbonation, and low warmth.

Bomber from The Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours slightly hazy gold with a creamy white head. Aroma is citrus, brett!, earthy, yeast/spice. Kids arent drinking this one! Near med body. It is earthy. Woody. Noticeably bretty. Astringent. Then theres some light citrus and light pitted fruit. Finishes reasonably earthy and bitter, with some brett. Amazing how a little brett just sets off a beer.

650mL bottle, purchased at City Beer Store. Pours a lightly hazy, golden-straw color; fluffy white head with solid retention and lacing. Doughy esters and some soft white-pepper notes alongside light, juicy citrus (lime) and mild funk of brett; both a filled-out nose and well-rangled yeast management that doesnt overstep. Vibrant carbonation and a medium-light body; lightly creamy texture. Some white pepper and a mild carbonic bite at the front of things, followed by dough and lime and the lightest funk; crackly Pils-like maltiness and even some modest tropical fruit hop character; a damn fine table beer. Nice dry, doughy finish with lingering bitterness. Great stuff, Brian.

650ml Bottle:  Aroma of malt, grain, fruit, yeast, flowers, light Brett, lavender, and some barnyard.  Poured yellow/gold in color with a small, creamy, dense, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Very hazy/cloudy.  Sparkling.  Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of malt, grain, yeast, light Brett, fruit, pepper, and hops.  Light body.  Oily, then dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Lightly sweet, lightly bitter, malt, light Brett, yeast, fruit, hop finish is lightly dry.

Bottle.  Pours hazy yellow with a large, frothy white head, medium retention with excellent lacing.  Aroma is barnyard and earthy yeast, citrus, floral and earthy hops, pepper and lavender.  Flavor is spices, barnyard and funky yeast with malt backbone and a very dry finish.  Light body and warmth, high carbonation.
Aroma is a mix of tropical fruit, yeast and a hint of tartness.  The flavor is tropical fruit/kiwi/lime, hops, a hard to describe yeast strain that leads into a dry finish.

Pours hazy gold with a foamy white head that sticks around. The aroma is of light Brett funk, a bit of earthy hops, and touch of citrus. The flavor is a great blend of light horsey Brett, some clove and  white pepper spice notes from the yeast, and a dry fairly bitter finish. Probably the best session beer I have had.

Bottle pours golden light orange with white head that is pretty light and fluffy. Aromas of oranges, like OJ from concentrate and some hay and funk. Tastes are hay, earthy,  some barnyard funkiness, and a nice clean bitter end. Body is alight with average carbonation and a dry bitter finish.  Very quaffable and would be a good beer if half the price.  Too expensive to drink that much of.
Bottle. Golden blonde color with a nice head that remains. Belgian yeasty flavor that light on the palate...almost like a saison. Excellent beer

Stillwaters done it again !  Pours a cloudy blondish color with good tingly head that laces out nicely opening up great aromas of pine, lemon, juniper and a touch of barnyard aromas on a chilly autumn morning.... a great prelude to what lies in the taste! Crisp dry peppery notes linger with earthy dusty roundness hitting underneath that crispness.  Great bitter finish with amazing complexity.
Draught at Beer Table, Brooklyn. Clear golden - white head. Spicy. Herbal. Peppery spicy notes. Light malty. Light citrus. Fruity. Dryness. Light flowery. Zesty. Nice freshness. Nice drinkability.

Draft at beer table. Very floral hop aroma with some light spice
Has real bite on the palate citrus hop, nice yeast characteristics
Dry finish with a lingering bitterness
UPDATED: APR 26, 2013 draft at brewery, light and pretty thin. A highly drinkable table session ale. Some belgian fruity notes in there.
